<h2>Distinguishing Features</h2>

Restricted to permanently moist, open bog habitats, variably green K. pauciflora forms a very fine (&lt;1/4 mm wide) filamentous fuzz in and amongst the sprigs of Sphagnum. The underleaves and lateral leaves are similair in form (if not size), both 3-4 lobed and sharply-tipped, the lobes widening from 1 cell at their tip to 2 cells at their bottom before joining to a wide leaf base that is attached to the stem at 90 degrees. 

<h2>Similar species</h2>

See notes under K. makinoana, from which K. pauciflora differs in having a 3-to-4 lobed underleaf while the former has an underleaf of 1-to-2 clear lobes in addition to some amorphous knobs (&quot;slime papillae&quot;). 

<h2>Habitat</h2>

Moist to wet, usually shady humus, decayed wood, rock outcrops, cliffs, bogs, and peatlands in the lowland, montane, and subalpine zones
